Brazil - Integrated Municipal Project -
            Betim Municipality

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Integrated Municipal
            Project - Betim Municipality for Brazil were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was significant, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: bank
            preparation of investment projects that target environmental
            improvements should deploy relevant specialized technical
            knowhow and experience effectively so that environmental
            problem are properly appraised and feasible targets set for
            improvements. For this project, illegal sewage discharge,
            that continues to pollute the river, needed more analysis
            and preventative action, while river water quality targets
            should have been more modest and achievable over a
            reasonable time period. The preparation of components in
            investment projects, especially key ones such as the Betim
            Central sewage treatment plant, should routinely take into
            account land acquisition, land use zoning, stakeholder
            commitment and site difficulties, to set a realistic and
            achievable path to implementation. Policies and actions to
            curb the causes of environmental degradation should be at
            the core of operations designed to improve the urban
            environment. The lesson from this project is the need to
            include measures to curb the illegal discharge of sewage,
            observed on site by the Independent Evaluation Group (IEG)
            mission in Betim that, if not curtailed, could bypass the
            environmental gains made by additional sewage treatment.

Brazil - Integrated Municipal Project -
            Betim Municipality

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Integrated Municipal
            Project - Betim Municipality for Brazil were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Lessons can also be learned from this project as a pilot
            experience in municipal lending for urban development and
            integrated urban water management projects: (i)
            municipalities are the primary actors in urban development:
            therefore, it is essential that in these type of projects a
            sense of priority and ownership is created among key actors
            in the municipal administration (mayor, secretaries and
            senior staff); (ii) integrated urban development projects
            such as these enhance local governments' capacity to
            manage complex interventions as well as strategic thinking
            on how cities must be (institutionally and physically)
            shaped; (iii) complex urban development projects can be
            managed effectively by medium-sized municipalities with a
            reasonable institutional and operational capacity; however,
            external support (by the Bank, consultants, etc.) is
            critical, especially in key issues such as project design,
            institutional strengthening, organizational reengineering,
            resettlement, complex engineering tasks, and fiduciary
            issues; and (iv) inter-sectoral arrangements cannot work at
            the level of the project or of the project management unit
            (UGP) alone; they must already exist, or be created in the
            municipality as a whole.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Integrated Municipal Project -
            Betim Municipality

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the project
            is to assist the municipality of Betim in: (a) promoting
            sustainable socio-environmental development, (b) reducing
            inequality, and (c) enhancing the city's quality of
            life through integrated investments in urban environment
            infrastructure and social services coupled with broader
            efforts to improve municipal governance, regulatory policy,
            and institutional strengthening. The project has the
            following four components: Component 1) will focus on
            strengthening policies, finance and management capacities of
            the Betim Municipality in key thematic areas: governance and
            planning; local service provision; and environmental
            management. Component 2) will finance short, medium and
            long-term initiatives to improve living conditions for poor
            and vulnerable families. It will also strengthen municipal
            social policies and programs through: resettling families
            living in risk-prone areas; support for physical
            improvements in poor communities; and strengthen municipal
            social policies and programs. Component 3) will invest in
            environmental improvement of the Betim River basin and in
            the quality of life of its inhabitants by: implementing and
            expanding basic urban environmental infrastructure,
            improving the protection of water resources by creating
            three urban parks (totaling 30 ha) and restoring riparian
            vegetation. Component 4) will establish a project management
            unit (UGP) responsible for managing and monitoring project
            implementation and coordinating civil works supervision and
            project auditing.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Integrated Municipal Project -
            Betim Municipality : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Integrated Municipal Project (Municipality of Betim)for
            Brazil evaluates the existing conditions, identifies the
            potential direct and indirect environmental impacts and
            proposes adequate mitigation measures for each negative
            impact identified, as well as measures for enhancing each
            identified positive impact. As part of the project
            objectives and design, the Project has a strong
            environmental emphasis, including strengthening the
            environmental institutional capacity of the environmental
            secretariat and the capacity of the regional river basin
            committee. Moreover, the Project will review environmental
            policies and regulations in order to scale up the municipal
            capacity to respond to the environmental  needs at the local
            level. While the Project is expected to result in
            significant positive impacts for biodiversity and natural
            habitats, short-term impacts to riverine habitats will
            result from making drainage improvements. These impacts will
            be more than mitigated by project interventions to
            rehabilitate Betim River tributaries through eradicating and
            treating polluting sources (building a wastewater treatment
            plant), resettling populations living within the
            floodplains, creating urban parks, and restoring wetland
            vegetation along the project waterways. Also, the project
            will ensure that urban drainage emphasizes the selection of
            alternatives that 1) maximize preservation, to the extent
            possible, of existing watercourses and "mata
            ciliar" vegetation; 2) use adjacent spaces to create or
            augment linear parks to promote environmental awareness
            among residents and to buffer urban impacts to streams; and
            3) strengthen the protection of existing parks or protected
            areas to maximize the long-term sustainability of water
            quality improvements. An environmental construction manual
            appended to all project infrastructure-related contracts
            will include activities to minimize and mitigate
            construction-related activities (such as noise, air
            pollution from dust, and water pollution from dredge
            sediments). Other activities involve public awareness and
            environmental education, replacement housing and cash
            compensation for involuntary displaced  households,
            identification of illegal household sewerage connections,
            dam safety and flood control management, technical and
            safety procedures for flood-retention basins, and dredge
            transport and disposal.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Integrated Municipal Project -
            Betim Municipality : environmental assessment executive summary

abstracts.cdata!:
The Betim Integrated Municipal Project
            for Brazil finances a secondary sewerage network; a sewerage
            treatment plant, drainage improvements, and secondary roads.
            This environmental assessment anticipates negative
            environmental impacts resulting from construction and
            suggests mitigation measures. Impacts include dust, noise
            pollution, erosion, water contamination, and removal of
            protected plant species. Moreover, 820 families in urban
            flood-prone areas will have to be involuntarily resettled
            and compensated accordingly. Short-term impacts to river
            habitats will be offset by treating river pollution sources,
            building a wastewater treatment plant, creating and managing
            urban parks, and restoring vegetation along all creeks
            affected by the project. Drainage program selection will
            maximize preserving existing water courses and "mata
            ciliar" vegetation; use adjacent spaces to create or
            augment linear parks to promote environmental awareness of
            residents and to buffer urban impacts to streams; and
            strengthen the protection of existing parks or protected
            areas. Homeowners will be required to properly connect to
            the sewerage network with costs borne by the property owner
            or the municipality. The EA also evaluated the operational
            and safety procedures for the Varzea das Flores Reservoir.
            The reservoir's operation will be coordinated with the
            flood control management plans for the Betim watershed and
            overseen by the state water company, with annual inspection
            reports produced. Routine operation and safety procedures
            will be set for the new flood-retention basins. A dredge
            materials manual will regulate the removal, transport, and
            disposal of dredged sediments. Environmental monitoring is
            included within several project components to assess the
            impact of project activities on water quality.

            socio-environmental municipal development, reduce poverty,
            improve urban environmental conditions, and enhance the
            city's quality of life. Public awareness will seek to
            promote community participation, and ensure adequate
            compensation to project affected people (PAP), and, that
            their living standards improve, or, are at least restored
            following project implementation. The RAP intends to
            minimize as possible the number of families to be resettled,
            ensure assistance options, and the compensation for
            replacement value of property, and improvements in housing
            structures, where needed. In addition, income generation
            shall be restored, and the provision of social services -
            education, health care, public transport - will be ensured.
            PAP will have the freedom of choice regarding the options of
            compensation - at replacement costs or cash compensation -
            within the criteria adopted by this RAP. Monitoring criteria
            will be in place to ensure compliance with the RAP
            framework, and, grievance mechanisms will be establish
            should conflict occur.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Integrated Municipal Project -
            Betim Municipality : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Integrated Municipal Project (Municipality of Betim)for
            Brazil evaluates the existing conditions, identifies the
            potential direct and indirect environmental impacts and
            proposes adequate mitigation measures for each negative
            impact identified, as well as measures for enhancing each
            identified positive impact. As part of the project
            objectives and design, the Project has a strong
            environmental emphasis, including strengthening the
            environmental institutional capacity of the environmental
            secretariat and the capacity of the regional river basin
            committee. Moreover, the Project will review environmental
            policies and regulations in order to scale up the municipal
            capacity to respond to the environmental  needs at the local
            level. While the Project is expected to result in
            significant positive impacts for biodiversity and natural
            habitats, short-term impacts to riverine habitats will
            result from making drainage improvements. These impacts will
            be more than mitigated by project interventions to
            rehabilitate Betim River tributaries through eradicating and
            treating polluting sources (building a wastewater treatment
            plant), resettling populations living within the
            floodplains, creating urban parks, and restoring wetland
            vegetation along the project waterways. Also, the project
            will ensure that urban drainage emphasizes the selection of
            alternatives that 1) maximize preservation, to the extent
            possible, of existing watercourses and "mata
            ciliar" vegetation; 2) use adjacent spaces to create or
            augment linear parks to promote environmental awareness
            among residents and to buffer urban impacts to streams; and
            3) strengthen the protection of existing parks or protected
            areas to maximize the long-term sustainability of water
            quality improvements. An environmental construction manual
            appended to all project infrastructure-related contracts
            will include activities to minimize and mitigate
            construction-related activities (such as noise, air
            pollution from dust, and water pollution from dredge
            sediments). Other activities involve public awareness and
            environmental education, replacement housing and cash
            compensation for involuntary displaced  households,
            identification of illegal household sewerage connections,
            dam safety and flood control management, technical and
            safety procedures for flood-retention basins, and dredge
            transport and disposal.
